content.text: The Best Christmas Pageant. The Herdmans were absolutely the worst kids in the history of the world.

They lied and stole and smoked cigars (even the girls) and talked dirty and hit little kids and cussed their teachers and took the name of the Lord in vain and set fire to Fred Shoemaker’s old broken-down toolhouse.
They were just plain awful.
They reigned over the school like a pack of wild animals, and if you got in their way, you were dead meat.
They didn’t even have normal names like other people.
They were named Ralph, Imogene, Leroy, Claude, Ollie, and Gladys—all six of them, and they were all in school together, which made it even worse.
The Herdmans lived over a garage at the bottom of Sproul Hill, in a part of town where the houses weren’t very nice and the people weren’t very nice either.
Their mother worked double shifts at the shoe factory, and their father had left town years ago, so the Herdmans were on their own most of the time.

They didn’t go to church, and they didn’t go to Sunday school, and they didn’t know anything about the Christmas story—except that there was a baby in it, and they didn’t see what was so special about that.
Every year at Christmastime, the ladies of the church put on a Christmas pageant, and every year it was the same.
Alice Wendleken played Mary, and Elmer Hopkins played Joseph, and the baby Jesus was a doll that belonged to Mrs.
Wendleken.
The shepherds wore bathrobes and carried crooks made out of cardboard, and the Wise Men brought gifts of gold (a tie clasp), frankincense (a bottle of perfume), and myrrh (a box of stationery).
The angels had tinsel halos and wings made out of coat hangers, and the whole thing was very dull and predictable.
But this year, everything changed.
It all started when my mother, who was in charge of the pageant, made the mistake of saying in Sunday school that there would be refreshments after the rehearsal.

The Herdmans had never been to Sunday school before, but they heard about the refreshments, and the very next Sunday, there they were—all six of them, sitting in the back row, looking like they’d been sent up from the county jail.
Mrs. Wendleken gasped when she saw them. “What are they doing here?” she whispered to my mother.
“They heard about the refreshments,” my mother said. “Well, they can’t stay,” Mrs. Wendleken said.
“They’ll ruin everything.”  But my mother said they could stay, and that was that.
The Herdmans stayed, and they ate all the refreshments—every last cookie and cupcake—and then they asked when the next rehearsal was.
“Next Sunday,” my mother said. “What time?” Imogene asked. “Three o’clock.”  “We’ll be here,” Imogene said, and they were.
Chapter Two: The Pageant Begins  The first rehearsal was a disaster.
The Herdmans didn’t know any of the parts, and they didn’t care.
They just sat in the back and made faces at the other kids.
When my mother asked who wanted to be Mary, Alice Wendleken raised her hand, but Imogene Herdman said, “I’ll be Mary.”  Alice gasped.
“You can’t be Mary! You don’t even know the story!”  “I know enough,” Imogene said.
“Mary was the mother of Jesus, and she had a baby in a barn.
Big deal.”  My mother tried to explain that Mary was very special, but Imogene just shrugged.
“I’ll be Mary,” she said again. And that was that. Imogene was Mary.
Then Leroy said he wanted to be Joseph, and Claude and Ollie said they wanted to be the Wise Men.
Gladys, who was the youngest and the meanest, said she wanted to be the Angel of the Lord, and Ralph, who was the oldest and the laziest, said he’d be a shepherd.
The other kids were horrified. “They can’t be in the pageant!” Alice Wendleken said.
“They’ll ruin it!”  But my mother said, “We’ll see.”  Chapter Three: The Rehearsals  The rehearsals were terrible.
The Herdmans didn’t know their lines, and they didn’t care.
Imogene refused to hold the baby Jesus doll because she said it was “just a dumb doll,” and Leroy kept trying to trade Joseph’s staff for a cigar.
The Wise Men brought gifts that weren’t gold, frankincense, or myrrh—they brought a ham sandwich, a yo-yo, and a slingshot.
Gladys, who was supposed to be the Angel of the Lord, kept yelling, “Hey!
Unto you a child is born!” at the top of her lungs, and Ralph, the shepherd, fell asleep in the middle of the pageant.
The other kids were furious. “This is the worst pageant ever!” Alice Wendleken said.
“The Herdmans are ruining everything!”  But my mother just sighed and said, “We’ll see.”  Chapter Four: The Night of the Pageant  On the night of the pageant, the church was packed.
Everyone in town had heard about the Herdmans being in the pageant, and they all wanted to see what would happen.
When the pageant started, Imogene marched down the aisle with Leroy, looking like she owned the place.
She didn’t look like a sweet, gentle Mary—she looked like a girl who was about to rob a bank.
And when she got to the front, she didn’t kneel down like Mary was supposed to.
She just stood there, hands on her hips, glaring at the audience. Then the Angel of the Lord appeared.
It was Gladys, and she didn’t look like an angel at all.
She looked like a wild animal, with her hair sticking out in all directions and her wings crooked.
And when she yelled, “Hey!
Unto you a child is born!” it sounded more like a threat than a proclamation.
The shepherds came in next, and Ralph was still half-asleep, but he managed to stumble along with the others.
The Wise Men brought their gifts—a ham sandwich, a yo-yo, and a slingshot—and the audience gasped.
But then something amazing happened.
Imogene picked up the baby Jesus doll, and for the first time, she looked at it like it was real.
She held it gently, like it was something precious, and when she spoke, her voice was soft.
“His name is Jesus,” she said, “and he’s the Son of God.”  And just like that, the pageant wasn’t silly anymore.
It was real. The audience was quiet, and you could feel something special in the air.
When the pageant was over, everyone clapped, and the Herdmans took a bow.
They didn’t look like the worst kids in the world anymore. They looked like they belonged there.
Afterward, my mother said, “That was the best Christmas pageant ever.”  And it was. The End
